column1: Tracking Logical Difference in Large-Scale Ontologies: A Forgetting-Based Approach

column3: Renate A. Schmidt@The University of Manchester
column4: Hao Feng@North China University of Science and Technology

column1: AAAI Technical Track: Knowledge Representation and Reasoning

This paper explores how the logical difference between two ontologies can be tracked using a forgetting-based or uniform interpolation (UI)-based approach. The idea is that rather than computing all entailments of one ontology not entailed by the other ontology
column3: only the strongest entailments not entailed in the other ontology are computed. To overcome drawbacks of existing forgetting/uniform interpolation tools we introduce a new forgetting method designed for the task of computing the logical difference between different versions of large-scale ontologies. The method is sound and terminating
column4: and can compute uniform interpolants for ALC-ontologies as large as SNOMED CT and NCIt. Our evaluation shows that the method can achieve considerably better success rates (>90%) and provides a feasible approach to computing the logical difference in large-scale ontologies
column5: as a case study on different versions of SNOMED CT and NCIt ontologies shows.
